Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cultural-Biological Research on Stress and Gestational Age

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research supported by this award will investigate the relationship between culture and biology through the lens of maternal stress and pregnancy outcomes, particularly pre-terms births. Previous research has shown that some of the variability in rates of premature birth and thus the health of newborn babies can be attributed to social and cultural factors. However, little is known about the mechanisms that connect poverty, racism, and other social determinants with gestational age at delivery. Oregon State University anthropology doctoral student, Holly Horan, with the supervision of Dr. Melissa Cheyney, will investigate the possibility that maternal stress may be one linking factor. This is an important problem because globally, an estimated 15 million infants are born preterm each year. Preterm delivery, defined as a live-birth before 37 weeks gestational age, is a leading cause of death among children under five years of age, and is associated with lifelong, chronic health issues for those children who survive delivery.

The research will be carried out in Puerto Rico which has the highest rate of preterm birth in the entire U.S. jurisdiction. Furthermore, the most common epidemiological variables linked to preterm birth (such as maternal age, smoking, maternal education, first trimester pre-natal care, and lacking health insurance) in other places do not account for the rate in Puerto Rico. Recently, however, researchers have suggested a new avenue of inquiry: a possible relationship between maternal stress and early delivery, although to date, findings from these studies have been equivocal due to methodological constraints. Therefore, Horan will refine stress research methods in order to more reliably characterize and examine relationships between cultural and biological factors. She will collect data with a mix of social and biological methods, including: participant observation; administering the Puerto Rican version of the Cohen Perceived Stress Scale (PSS) and the Revised Prenatal Distress Questionnaire (RPDQ); hair cortisol concentration (HCC) sampling; and semi-structured postpartum exit interviews. She will identify cultural models of maternal stress using exploratory, semi-structured interviews with an initial 25 participants. The PSS, RPDQ, and HCCs will be assessed at three points during gestation (10 to 12 weeks, 22 to 24 weeks, and 34 to 36 weeks) in an additional 100 women in order to identify trends in stress experiences and hormones by trimester. An exit interview will be conducted between four to eight weeks postpartum and a fourth and final hair cortisol sample will be collected from these 100 participants. Hair cortisol concentrations (HCCs) will be used to investigate the utility of a simple, non-invasive cortisol measure as a longitudinal, biological proxy of maternal stress experiences. This study has the potential to result in a more comprehensive understanding of the social and structural etiologies associated with maternal stress and poor maternal and infant health outcomes. These findings will be of interest to policy makers as well as to researchers who seek to understand the connections between society, culture, and biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the close mentorship of Dr. Melissa Cheyney (PI), Holly Horan (Co-PI) investigated how maternal perceptions of stress in a United States (US) territory/colony determined whether, and if so, to what extent perceived material stress contributes to the high rate of preterm birth in Puerto Rico. Cheyney and Horan crafted a two-phase qualitative and quantitative bio-cultural, medical anthropological research project that had the potential to advance four methodologies identified in the chronic-stress and birth outcomes literature, including: 1) the utility of measuring pregnant women’s subjective stress experiences; 2) hair cortisol concentration (HCC) sampling methods and its ability to predict timing of delivery; 3) the validity of HCC levels as a measurable reflection of subjective stress experiences; and 4) how theories central to medical anthropological research can help elucidate relationships between US colonial contexts, maternal stress, pregnancy, and poor birth outcomes. Cheyney and Horan also outlined five potential benefits to society as an outcome of this research, including: 1) providing a more comprehensive understanding of the social and system-level issues associated with maternal stress and poor maternal and infant health outcomes in Puerto Rico; 2) informing policy advocates and health economists in Puerto Rico; 3) promoting the position of more sustainable, holistic models of care such as mother-led, maternity care; 4) training female research assistants (RAs) from Puerto Rico; 5) training Horan, a Latina doctoral student of Puerto Rican descent. After 16 months of data collection, preliminary findings suggest that anthropological methods can nuance our understanding of maternal stress measures and the associated circumstances or conditions that contribute to timing of birth. 

The first phase of this project built a cultural context for stress and pregnancy in Puerto Rico using open-ended, semi-structured interviews and participant observation. Concurrently, ZIKV (the Zika virus) was declared a public health emergency on the island – resulting in participant narratives that included Zika-specific stressors during pregnancy. Findings suggest that ZIKV compounded the impact of the island’s socioeconomic stressors and that ZIKV and its subsequent public health campaigns for long-term birth control were questioned as another form of reproductive colonization. Phase I data also contributed to the development of four questions that were added to the existing, validated stress scales used in phase II: the 10-question Cohen-Perceived Stress Scale (CSS) and the Revised Prenatal Distress Questionnaire (RPDQ). The CSS and RPDQ were administered by Horan and local Puerto Rican RAs at each prenatal visit and the initial findings reflect that overall, participants had moderate levels of generalized and pregnancy-specific stress with elevated stress levels in the first and third trimesters. Horan and RAs also collected an HCC sample at each prenatal visit. Findings suggest that participant HCCs followed the expected trend of cortisol levels during pregnancy – rising slowly in the first and second trimesters and increasing significantly in the third trimester with a slight decrease in the early postpartum period. These preliminary findings indicate that the trends in the stress scale data do not match the trends of HCC data during pregnancy, thus calling for a more nuanced understanding of perceived maternal stress and its association with physiological experiences of stress and timing of birth – all against the backdrop of the cultural context in which stress is perceived and experienced.  

At the end of phase II, Horan and RAs completed semi-structured postpartum interviews which included patient reported outcomes and open-ended questions asking participants about their stress experiences in general and as reflected in their responses to the stress scales. Early findings from these interviews indicate that participants had common stressors associated with pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester and in the third trimester. Participant narratives also highlighted the utility of the stress scales as a quick assessment and personal-check on their own stress levels, while also critiqing the scales for solely identifying stressful feelings or experiences, but not including space to explain how these stressors occurred and impacted their daily lives. Findings from patient reported outcomes, such as number of weeks pregnant at time of delivery, suggest the possibility that persistently low levels of physiologic stress during pregnancy could be associated with timing of delivery independent of stress scale responses. These preliminary findings suggest a possible relationship between the “wear and tear” of the human stress response system due to chronic stress and timing of delivery – expanding the approach of stress and prematurity research from focusing on solely high-cortisol levels and timing of delivery, to considering the role of flattened cortisol responses in pregnancy as well.

The earliest findings from this project have been shared at the 2017 American Physical Anthropology meetings and the 2018 International Normal Labour and Birth conference. In-depth data analysis will continue in the summer and fall of 2018 with plans for dissemination with local partners, at professional conferences, and in peer-reviewed journals occurring over the 2018-2019 academic year.


Last Modified: 07/20/2018
Modified by: Holly L Horan
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: With the close mentorship of Dr. Melissa Cheyney (PI), Holly Horan (Co-PI) investigated how maternal perceptions of stress in a United States (US) territory/colony determined whether, and if so, to what extent perceived material stress contributes to the high rate of preterm birth in Puerto Rico. Cheyney and Horan crafted a two-phase qualitative and quantitative bio-cultural, medical anthropological research project that had the potential to advance four methodologies identified in the chronic-stress and birth outcomes literature, including: 1) the utility of measuring pregnant women?s subjective stress experiences; 2) hair cortisol concentration (HCC) sampling methods and its ability to predict timing of delivery; 3) the validity of HCC levels as a measurable reflection of subjective stress experiences; and 4) how theories central to medical anthropological research can help elucidate relationships between US colonial contexts, maternal stress, pregnancy, and poor birth outcomes. Cheyney and Horan also outlined five potential benefits to society as an outcome of this research, including: 1) providing a more comprehensive understanding of the social and system-level issues associated with maternal stress and poor maternal and infant health outcomes in Puerto Rico; 2) informing policy advocates and health economists in Puerto Rico; 3) promoting the position of more sustainable, holistic models of care such as mother-led, maternity care; 4) training female research assistants (RAs) from Puerto Rico; 5) training Horan, a Latina doctoral student of Puerto Rican descent. After 16 months of data collection, preliminary findings suggest that anthropological methods can nuance our understanding of maternal stress measures and the associated circumstances or conditions that contribute to timing of birth. The first phase of this project built a cultural context for stress and pregnancy in Puerto Rico using open-ended, semi-structured interviews and participant observation. Concurrently, ZIKV (the Zika virus) was declared a public health emergency on the island – resulting in participant narratives that included Zika-specific stressors during pregnancy. Findings suggest that ZIKV compounded the impact of the island?s socioeconomic stressors and that ZIKV and its subsequent public health campaigns for long-term birth control were questioned as another form of reproductive colonization. Phase I data also contributed to the development of four questions that were added to the existing, validated stress scales used in phase II: the 10-question Cohen-Perceived Stress Scale (CSS) and the Revised Prenatal Distress Questionnaire (RPDQ). The CSS and RPDQ were administered by Horan and local Puerto Rican RAs at each prenatal visit and the initial findings reflect that overall, participants had moderate levels of generalized and pregnancy-specific stress with elevated stress levels in the first and third trimesters. Horan and RAs also collected an HCC sample at each prenatal visit. Findings suggest that participant HCCs followed the expected trend of cortisol levels during pregnancy – rising slowly in the first and second trimesters and increasing significantly in the third trimester with a slight decrease in the early postpartum period. These preliminary findings indicate that the trends in the stress scale data do not match the trends of HCC data during pregnancy, thus calling for a more nuanced understanding of perceived maternal stress and its association with physiological experiences of stress and timing of birth – all against the backdrop of the cultural context in which stress is perceived and experienced. At the end of phase II, Horan and RAs completed semi-structured postpartum interviews which included patient reported outcomes and open-ended questions asking participants about their stress experiences in general and as reflected in their responses to the stress scales. Early findings from these interviews indicate that participants had common stressors associated with pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester and in the third trimester. Participant narratives also highlighted the utility of the stress scales as a quick assessment and personal-check on their own stress levels, while also critiqing the scales for solely identifying stressful feelings or experiences, but not including space to explain how these stressors occurred and impacted their daily lives. Findings from patient reported outcomes, such as number of weeks pregnant at time of delivery, suggest the possibility that persistently low levels of physiologic stress during pregnancy could be associated with timing of delivery independent of stress scale responses. These preliminary findings suggest a possible relationship between the "wear and tear" of the human stress response system due to chronic stress and timing of delivery – expanding the approach of stress and prematurity research from focusing on solely high-cortisol levels and timing of delivery, to considering the role of flattened cortisol responses in pregnancy as well. The earliest findings from this project have been shared at the 2017 American Physical Anthropology meetings and the 2018 International Normal Labour and Birth conference. In-depth data analysis will continue in the summer and fall of 2018 with plans for dissemination with local partners, at professional conferences, and in peer-reviewed journals occurring over the 2018-2019 academic year.
